text:
He ended all the confusion with his sister so gently—just by reaching out his hand at the right moment and looking at her like that. He has such nice eyes and a nice face! He even looks better than Dounia. But, oh my, what a terrible suit he’s wearing! Vasya, the messenger boy from Afanasy Ivanitch’s shop, is dressed better! I feel like I could run up to him and hug him and cry, but I’m scared. Why am I scared?

“Oh, Rodya, you wouldn’t believe how unhappy Dounia and I were yesterday!” she suddenly said, eager to respond to him. “Now that it’s all over and we’re happy again, I can tell you. Imagine, we rushed here straight from the train to hug you and that woman—oh, there she is! Good morning, Nastasya! She told us right away that you were lying in a high fever and had just run away from the doctor in a daze, and they were looking for you in the streets. You can’t imagine how worried we were! I couldn’t stop thinking about the sad story of Lieutenant Potanchikov, a friend of your dad’s—you probably don’t remember him, Rodya—who ran out like that in a high fever and fell into the well in the courtyard. They couldn’t get him out until the next day. Of course, we were exaggerating. We almost rushed to find Pyotr Petrovitch to ask for help… because we were all alone, completely alone,” she said sadly, then paused, remembering it was still a bit risky to talk about Pyotr Petrovitch, even though “we are quite happy again.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov's sister expresses her concern for him while reflecting on their recent struggles and the relief of being reunited.
